p: Interestingly, compounds 5g and 5h showing best anti-tubercular activity with the minimal bacterial resistance against resistant-TB, revealed a broad-spectrum antibacterial action against most of the tested bronchitis causing-bacteria. They were found to be more potent than the reference drug against H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis, and B. pertussis (MIC = 0.24–3.9 µg/mL, Azithromycin MIC = 3.9–7.81 µg/mL). Additionally, they were equipotent to Azithromycin against M. pneumoniae, S. pneumoniae and K. pneumoniae (MIC = 1.95, 0.98, and 0.49 µg/mL, respectively).
